Article.ArticleTitle: Geographic sources of ozone air pollution and mortality burden in Europe.

AbstractText: Ground-level ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) is a harmful air pollutant formed in the atmosphere by the interaction between sunlight and precursor gases. Exposure to current O<sub>3</sub> levels in Europe is a major source of premature mortality from air pollution. However, mitigation actions have been mainly designed and implemented at the national and regional scales, lacking a comprehensive assessment of the geographic sources of O<sub>3</sub> pollution and its associated health impacts. Here we quantify both national and imported contributions to O<sub>3</sub> and their related mortality burden across 813 contiguous regions in 35 European countries, representing about 530 million people. Imported O<sub>3</sub> contributed to 88.3% of all O<sub>3</sub>-attributable deaths (intercountry range 83-100%). The greatest share of imported O<sub>3</sub> had its origins outside the study domain (that is, hemispheric sources), which was responsible for 56.7% of total O<sub>3</sub>-attributable mortality (range 42.5-87.2%). It was concluded that achieving the air-quality guidelines set out by the World Health Organization and avoiding the health impacts of O<sub>3</sub> require not only the implementation of national or coordinated pan-European actions but also global strategies.
